title: Introduction to `sasr`
text: functionality wrapped sasr, can find documentations R documentation system, online documentation page. However, can arguments documented(...), arguments described saspy documentation page.

title: Introduction to `sasr`
text: use sasr, need follow steps sascfg() creates ssh based SAS session. password-less ssh connection supported, e.g. ssh via public keys. host hostname SAS server. saspath SAS executable path SAS server. arguments added configuration file directly. tunnel rtunnel required want transfer datasets R SAS client (running sasr) reachable server. Use integers like tunnel = 9999L R, modify sascfg_personal.py make sure integers. can create configuration SAS connection restricted ssh. can multiple configuration files different file names session created session available stored .sasr_env$.sas_session .sasr_env$.sas_session created, session used default. create variable called .sas_session environment sasr:::.sasr_env SAS_session one argument sascfg, pointing SAS session configuration file. use multiple sessions, need store session your_session <- sas_session(sascfg) Tunneling must enabled transfer datasets. variable names datasets contain dots otherwise SAS may recognize. index (row names) transferred SAS. returned value named list, LST result LOG log file run_sas argument results=, can either “TEXT” “HTML”. argument decides LST format. Transfer SAS datasets back R use sd2df

title: SAS Interface
text: install sasr, please use following command {r} remotes::install_github(repo = 'insightsengineering/sasr') Reticulate installed automatically, Python package saspy . Python, can use following code install Python, can installed automatically call python related stuffs. {r} library(reticulate) install_python() install saspy, use following code {r} library(sasr) install_saspy() installation completes, ready use sasr package.

title: SAS Interface
text: ```{r} library(sasr) df2sd(mtcars, “mt”) result <- run_sas(” proc freq data = mt; run; “) cat(result$LOG) cat(result$LST) ```

title: SAS Interface
text: Q: use saspy instead using ssh tunnels? : Although can use ssh tunnels transfer data execute SAS commands, many restrictions: supports ssh connection. Using saspy, official Python interface SAS, can enable connection types, without reinventing wheel, e.g. can also connect local SAS installation syntax, connect remote SAS Viya http. addition, SAS sessions saspy end terminate (encounter net work issues), nice execute multiple SAS code one one, necessarily putting one script execute whole script . Also, update saspy time, sasr easily extensible, include functionalities transferring data executing SAS code.

title: Create SAS Session Configuration File — sascfg
code: sascfg(   name = "default",   host,   saspath,   ssh = system("which ssh", intern = TRUE),   encoding = "latin1",   options = list("-fullstimer"),   ...,   sascfg = "sascfg_personal.py" )

title: Create SAS Session Configuration File — sascfg
text: name (character) name configuration. host (character) host name remote server. saspath (character) SAS executable path remote server. ssh (character) executable path ssh. encoding (character) encoding SAS session. options (list) additional list arguments pass ssh command. ... additional arguments. sascfg (character) target file configuration.
